The '''Yarsan''' or '''Ahle Haqq''' ({{lang-ku|یارسان}}, ''Yarsan'',<ref>{{cite book |title=Syncretistic Religious Communities in the Near East |editor=Krisztina Kehl-Bodrogi |display-editors=etal |first=M. Reza Fariborz |last=Hamzeh'ee |pages=101–117 |year=1995 |isbn=90-04-10861-0 |publisher=Brill |location=Leiden}}</ref><ref>P. G. Kreyenbroek (1992). Review of ''The Yaresan: A Sociological, Historical and Religio-Historical Study of a Kurdish Community'', by M. Reza Hamzeh'ee, 1990, {{ISBN|3-922968-83-X}}. ''Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies'', University of London, Vol.55, No.3, pp.565-566.</ref> {{lang-fa|اهل حق}}; "People of Truth"), is a [[syncretism|syncretic]] religion founded by [[Sultan Sahak]] in the late 14th century in western Iran.<ref>Elahi, Bahram (1987). ''The path of perfection, the spiritual teachings of Master Nur Ali Elahi''. {{ISBN|0-7126-0200-3}}.</ref> The total number of Yarsanis estimated at around 2,000,000 or 3,000,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looklex.com/e.o/ahl-e_haqq.htm|title=Yarsan population}}</ref>. Primarily found in western Iran and eastern Iraq, mostly ethnic [[Guran (Kurdish tribe)|Goran Kurds]],<ref>Edmonds, Cecil. Kurds, Turks, and Arabs: politics, travel, and research in north-eastern Iraq, 1919-1925. Oxford University Press, 1957.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kurdistanica.com/english/religion/yazdani/cult.html |title=Religion: Cult of Angels |work=Encyclopaedia Kurdistanica |accessdate=2006-09-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060828201511/http://www.kurdistanica.com/english/religion/yazdani/cult.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=2006-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://lexicorient.com/e.o/uyazdanism.htm|title=Yazdanism |work=Encyclopaedia of the Orient |accessdate=2006-11-25 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021160401/http://lexicorient.com/e.o/uyazdanism.htm|archivedate=21 October 2006 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> though there are also smaller groups of [[Turkish people|Turk]], [[Persian people|Persian]], [[Lori people|Lori]], [[Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]] and [[Arabs|Arab]] adherents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahle-haqq.com/beliefs.html|title=Ahl-e Haqq - Principle Beliefs and Convictions|publisher=|accessdate=23 August 2015}}</ref> Some Yarsanis in Iraq are called ''Kaka'i''. Yarsanis are also found in some rural communities in southeastern [[Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looklex.com/e.o/ahl-e_haqq.htm|title=Ahl-e Haqq - LookLex Encyclopaedia|author=Tore Kjeilen |publisher=|accessdate=23 August 2015}}</ref> Yarsanis say that some people call them disparagingly as "Ali-o-allahi" or "worshipers of [[Ali]]" which labels Yarsanis deny. Many Yarsanis hide their religion due to pressure of Iran's Islamic system, and there are no exact statistics of their population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bbc.com/persian/iran/2011/11/111127_l95_ahlehagh_jia_vid.shtml|title=Yarsan population}}</ref>
The Yarsanis have a distinct religious literature primarily written in the [[Gorani language (Zaza-Gorani)|Gorani language]] which also is known as [[Hawrami dialects]]. However, few modern Yarsani can read or write Gorani (a Northwestern Iranian language belonging to the branch Zaza-Gorani) as their mother tongues are [[Southern Kurdish]] and [[Sorani Kurdish]], which belong to the other two branches of the Kurdish language family. The speakers of [[Sarli dialect|Sarli,]] living near [[Al-Hamdaniya District|Eski Kalak]] are adherents, as [[Cecil J. Edmonds|Edmonds]] (1957: 195) and Moosa (1988: 168) observed. Their central religious book is called the ''[[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]]'', written in the 15th century based on the teachings of [[Sultan Sahak]].
The goal of Yarsanism is to teach humans to achieve ultimate truth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looklex.com/e.o/ahl-e_haqq.htm|title=Haghighat time}}</ref> The Yarsani believe sun and fire are holy things and follow the principles of equalization, purity, righteousness, and oneness, which leads some researchers to find [[Mithraism|Mithraic]] roots in this religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bbc.com/persian/iran/2011/11/111127_l95_ahlehagh_jia_vid.shtml|title=Mithraism's roots in Yarsani rituals}}</ref>
Yarsanism is barely mentioned in historical religious books as its doctrine and rituals are largely secret.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurdanyarsan.blogspot.se|title=why is there no name of Yarsanism in the old religious books?}}</ref> The followers of Yarsanism perform their rituals and ceremonies in secret, but this has not relieved the harassment of many of the Yarsani by Islamic or other governments over the centuries. The followers of this religion say that after the Islamic Revolution in Iran, pressure on the Yarsani community has increased and they have been deprived and discriminated against for over 30 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/persian/blog-viewpoints-39211631|title="discrimination over yarsan"}}</ref>
One of the signs of Yarsanic males is an intact mustache, as the Yarsanic holy book [[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]] says that every man must have a mustache to take part in Yarsanic religious rites.<ref>{{Yarsanism holy book Kalâm-e Saranjâm||title=mustache in yarsan}}</ref>
==Beliefs== [[File:Tambur.jpg|100px|thumb|right|The [[Kurdish tanbur|Tambur]] is a sacred symbol of Yarsanism and is played during religious ceremonies]] The Yarsani follow the mystical teachings of [[Sultan Sahak]]. From the Yarsani point of view, the universe is composed of two distinct yet interrelated worlds: the internal (''[[Batin (Islam)|Bātinī]]'') and the external (''[[Zahir (Islam)|zāhirī]]''), each having its own order and rules. Although humans are only aware of the outer world, their lives are governed according to the rules of the inner world. This aspect of the Yarsani faith can be identified as [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] [[esoterism]] which emerged under the intense influence of [[Batiniyyah|Bātinī]]-[[Sufism]] during the last two centuries.
Among other important pillars of their belief system are that the Divine Essence has successive manifestations in human form (''mazhariyyat'') and the belief in [[transmigration of the soul]] (''dunaduni'' in [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]]). Yarasani believe that every man needs to do what is written within their holy book, the [[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]], otherwise they are not part of Yarsan. There is no compulsion or exclusion in Yarsan – anyone who chooses to follow its precepts is welcome.
The Yarsani faith's features include [[millenarism]], [[Innatism]], [[egalitarianism]], [[metempsychosis]], [[angelology]], divine manifestation and [[Dualistic cosmology|dualism]]. Many of these features are found in [[Yazidism]], and they also have many things in common with [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]] and [[Christianity|Christians]]. Unlike other indigenous Persian faiths, the Yarsanism explicitly reject class, caste and rank, which sets them apart from the [[Yezidis]] and [[Zoroastrians]].<ref name="Hamzeh'ee">{{Cite book |last=Hamzeh'ee |first=M Reza |publication-date=1990 |year=1990 |title=The Yaresan: A Sociological, Historical, and Religio-historical Study of a Kurdish Community |edition= |series=[[Islamkundliche Untersuchungen]] |volume=138 |publication-place=Berlin |publisher=Schwartz |isbn=3-922968-83-X}}</ref>
===Epochs of Evolution=== According to Yarsani philosophy, the universe is evolving in through different Epochs<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fa.wikipedia.org/wiki/اهل_حق|title= levels of evolution In Yarsanism philosophy}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=May 2017}} and that these Epochs are:
1. First Epoch, or ''Shari'at,'' which includes the period from [[Adam and Eve]] until [[Muhammad]], also known as the "Prophet" period.<ref name="auto1">[[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]]</ref>
2. Second Epoch, or ''Tariqat,'' which includes the period from [[Ali|Ali ibn Abi Talib]] until [[Shah Khoshin]], also known as the "Doctrine" period.<ref name="auto1"/>
3. Third Epoch, or ''Marefat'', which includes the period from Shah Khoshin until [[Sultan Sahak]], also known as the "Mystical" period.<ref name="auto1"/>
4. Fourth Epoch, or ''Haqiqat'', which includes the period from [[Sultan Sahak]] until today, also known as the "Truth" period.<ref name="auto1"/>
===Divine manifestations=== The Yarsani are [[emanation]]ists and incarnationists, believing that the Divine Essence has successive [[incarnation]]s known as ''mazhariyyats'' (similar to the [[Hindu]] [[avatar]]s). They believe God manifests one primary and seven secondary manifestations in each epoch of the world, in either angel or human form. These seven persons are known as "''Haft tan''" which means "The Seven Persons"<ref name="auto1"/>
The primary ''mazhariyyat'' of the First Epoch was the Divine Essence known as Khawandagar, who created the world.
The primary ''mazhariyyat'' of the Second Epoch was [[Ali|Ali ibn Abi Talib]], the fourth [[Caliph]] and first imam of [[Shia Islam]]. This explains the alternative name for Yarsanis '''Ali-Allahi''', 'Believers in the divinity of Ali'.
The primary ''mazhariyyat'' of the Third Epoch was Shah Khoshin.
In the Fourth Epoch, the primary ''mazhariyyat'' is held to be [[Sultan Sahak]]. It is said that he was given birth by Dayerak Rezbar or Khatun-e Rezbar, a Kurdish virgin, and as in the case of [[Mary, the mother of Jesus|Mary]], it was a virginal conception. While sleeping under a [[pomegranate]] tree a kernel of fruit fell into her mouth when a bird pecked the fruit directly over her.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Kurds: History and Culture |url=http://www.bakhawan.com/dotkurd/nebez/Inglizi/TheKurds.pdf |page=23 |author=Nebez, Jamal |publisher=Western Kurdistan Association |date=1997-09-19 |accessdate=2006-09-01 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060525152728/http://www.bakhawan.com/dotkurd/nebez/Inglizi/TheKurds.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=2006-05-25 |authorlink=Jamal Nebez}}</ref>
[[File:kakkai.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Kurdish Yarsani men in [[Suleimaniyah]], [[Kurdistan Region]]. The picture on the wall contains [[religious symbolism]] of the sacred [[Kurdish tanbur]].]] According to Yarsani legend<ref>http://www.hum.uu.nl/medewerkers/m.vanbruinessen/publications/Bruinessen_Haji_Bektash_Soltan_Sahak.pdf</ref> after Sultan Sahak had completed the revelation of his esoteric teachings (''haqiqat'') to his first disciples among the Guran he took his leave of them. Disappearing from the Guran country without a trace, he reappeared in Anatolia in the form of [[Haji Bektash Veli]]. He taught mystical doctrines and techniques (''tariqat'') in those lands for almost a hundred years, and then returned to the Guran country. In the perception of his disciples there, he had been away for only an hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rbedrosian.com/Ref/Moosa/mmes18.htm|title=Sultan Sahak: Founder of the Ahl-i Haqq|first=Matti|last=Moosa|publisher=}}</ref>
===Haft Tan or seven persons=== Each Epoch in Yarsani belief saw the appearance of the seven secondary divine manifestations or ''Haft Tan''. In the First Epoch they appeared in their true angelic form, while in subsequent Epochs they appeared in human incarnations. The "''Haft Tan''" are charged with responsibility for the affairs of the internal realm.
The secondary ''mazhariyyats'' of the First Epoch include the archangels [[Gabriel]], [[Michael]], [[Israfil]] and [[Azrael]], and a female angelic being.
The ''mazhariyyats'' of the Second Epoch include Salman, Qanbar, [[Mohammed]], Nusayr (who is either [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]] or [[Theophobus]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news-contents.blogspot.ie/2011/12/ahl-e-haq.html|title=Ahl-e Haq|website=news-contents.blogspot.ie}}</ref> and [[Bahlool]]. It also includes [[Fatimah]], the daughter of Mohammed as the incarnation of the female angel.
The ''mazhariyyats'' of the Third Epoch include [[فضل‌الله نعیمی|Shah Fazlullah Veli]], Baba Sarhang Dudani and Baba Naous.
In the Fourth Epoch, the ''Haft Tan'' or 'seven persons' charged by Sultan Sahak with responsibility for the affairs of the inner realm consist of the following:<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/ZMHFaithRitualCultureAmongAH|title=Faith Ritual and Culture Among Ahle-Haqq|publisher=|via=Internet Archive}}</ref>
The "''Haft Tan''" (The Seven [[Archangels]]) are key figures in the Yarsani belief system and their history. The only female among them is Khatun-e Rezbar, the mother of Sultan Sahak. # Pir Benjamin, considered the [[incarnation]] of the archangel [[Gabriel]];and he has the preceptor title to all Yarsanis (Monday) # Pir Musi, the [[incarnation]] of the archangel [[Michael]] and known as [[Recording angel]] (Tuesday) # Mustafā'Dawan, the incarnation of archangel [[Azrael]] (Wednesday) # [[Sultan Sahak]], the incarnation of Divine Essence (Thursday) # Baba Yadegar, Also known as "''Ahmad''" and "''Reza''" (Friday) # Khatun-e Razbar. (Saturday) # Dawud koswar (David) Notice slang called Daoo, He is known as "''Dalil''" (in Kurdish Language) to all Yarsanis (Sunday) <ref>{{[[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]]|title=yarsan holy book}}</ref>
These seven persons are known as "''Haft tan''" Which means by word "The Seven Persons" <ref>{{[[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]]|title=yarsan holy book}}</ref>
===Transmigration of the soul=== Yarsanis also have a belief in [[transmigration of the soul]] (''dunaduni'' in [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]]). The Yarsani have a famous saying about death; "Men! Do not fear the punishment of death! The death of man is like the dive which the duck makes."<ref>{{cite book |last=Milani |first=Milad |year= 2013 |page= 110 |title= Sufism in the Secret History of Persia |isbn= 978-1-84465-677-6|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PfTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA110}}</ref> Human beings go through a cycle of 1001 incarnations. During this process, they may become more purified based on their actions. This process is confined however, only to Yarsanis - the ''zarda-gel'' or people created of yellow clay. Everyone else belongs to the ''ḵāk-e sīāh'' or people created of black earth, and are eternally damned.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ahl-e-haqq-people|title=AHL-E ḤAQQ – Encyclopaedia Iranica|first=|last=electricpulp.com|website=www.iranicaonline.org}}</ref>
===Holy Texts=== The traditions of the Yarsani are preserved in poetry known as ''[[Kalam-e Saranjam]]'' (''The Discourse of Conclusion''), divinely revealed narratives passed down orally through the generations. These traditions are said to have been written down by Pir Musi, one of the seven companions of Sultan Sahak (also the angel in charge of recording human deeds).<ref name="mirhosseini">Z. Mir-Hosseini (1994). "Inner Truth and Outer History: The Two Worlds of the Ahl-e Haqq of Kurdistan", ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'', Vol.26, pp.267-269.</ref> The collection consists of the epochs of Khawandagar [God], ‘Alī, Shah Khoshin and Sultan Sahak, the different manifestations of [[divinity]]. The epoch of Shah Khoshin takes place in [[Lorestān Province|Luristan]] and the epoch of Sultan Sahak is placed in [[Hawraman]] near the [[Diyala River|Sirwan River]], the land of the [[Southern Kurdish|Goranî]]. Also important to the [[Southern Kurdish|Goranî]] is the Daftar-e kezana-ye Perdivari (''Book of the Treasure of Perdivar''), a collection of twenty six mythological poems or ''kalams''.<ref name="auto"/>
The sayings attributed to Sultan Sahak are written in [[Gorani language (Zaza-Gorani)|Gorani]] Kurdish, the sacred language of the Ahl-e Haqq, which also is known as [[Hawrami dialects]]. However, few modern Yarsani can read or write Gorani (a Northwestern Iranian language belonging to the branch Zaza-Gorani) as their mother tongues are [[Southern Kurdish]] and [[Sorani Kurdish]], which belong to the other two branches of the Kurdish language family. Some Yarsani literature is written in the Persian language.<ref name="leezenberg">{{cite web |last=Leezenberg |first=Michiel |url=http://home.hum.uva.nl/oz/leezenberg/GInflCK.rtf |title=Gorani Influence on Central Kurdish: Substratum or Prestige Borrowing? |format= [[Rich Text Format|RTF]]}}</ref>
==Worship== ===Holy Sites=== [[File:Dawu Tomb Zarde Village.JPG|200px|thumb|right|The Holy Tomb of Dawoud is one of the sacred shrines of Yarsinism]] Two important sanctuaries of the Yarsani are the tomb of Bābā Yādgār about 40km away from [[Sarpol-e Zahab]] in [[Kermanshah Province]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://historicaliran.blogspot.ie/2009/12/baba-yadegar-shrine.html|title=Baba Yadegar Shrine|website=historicaliran.blogspot.ie}}</ref> and the tomb of Dawoud at [[Zardeh, Dalahu|Zarde]] about three kilometres east of Sarpol-e Zahab.<ref> http://www.let.uu.nl/~martin.vanbruinessen/personal/publications/Bruinessen_Veneration_of_Satan_among_the_Ahl-i_Haqq_of_Guran.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livius.org/articles/place/dukkan-e-daud/?|title=Dukkan-e Daud - Livius|website=www.livius.org}}</ref> Another important shrine is that of Sultan Suhak in [[Sheykhan, Kermanshah|Sheykhan]] near Perdīvar bridge in Kermanshah Province.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahle-haqq.com/formation.html|title=Ahl-e Haqq - Formation of the Order|website=www.ahle-haqq.com}}</ref><ref name="auto"/> The tombs of Pir Benjamin and Pir Musi in the town of [[Kerend]] in [[Kermanshah Province]], Iran are also important shrines.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.academia.edu/10772192/The_Cults_of_the_Angels_The_Indigenous_Religions_of_Kurdistan|title=The Cults of the Angels: The Indigenous Religions of Kurdistan|first=L K|last=Robert|publisher=}}</ref>
===Customs=== One of Yarsani men's apparent signs is to have a full moustache, because in the holy book [[Kalâm-e Saranjâm]] it says that every man has to have a moustache to take part in their religious rites.
The concourse of Yarsanis is called the ''jam khana.'' They gather there for [[:tr:Ehl-i Hakk Âyin-î Cemi|Ahl-e Haqq Jam]] similar to [[Jem (Alevism)|Jem]] in [[Alevism]] and they use ''[[Kurdish tanbur|tambour]]'' for meditation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmM2-I0EZXM|title=یه شبی زار و پریشان در میخانه زدم|f irst=|last=Amir Drs|date=22 December 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Organisation== ===Khandans or spiritual houses=== Yarsanism is organised into spiritual houses or Khandans, seven of which were established at the time of Sultan Sahak, and four afterwards, making eleven Khandans in all. The Khandans were established when, along with the ''Haft Tan'', Sultan Sahak also formed the ''Haft Tawane'', a group of seven holy persons charged with the affairs of the outer world.<ref name="auto2"/> They were Say-yed Mohammad, Say-yed Abu'l Wafa, Haji Babusi, Mir Sur, Say-yed Mostafa, Sheykh Shahab al-Din and Sheykh Habib Shah. Each of the ''Haft Tawane'' was charged with responsibility for the guidance of a number of followers, and these followers formed the original seven Khandans, namely Shah Ebrahim, Baba Yadegar, Ali Qalandar, Khamush, Mir Sur, Sey-yed Mosaffa and Hajji Babu Isa. After Sultan Sahak's time another four khandans were established, namely Atesh Bag, Baba Heydar, Zolnour and Shah Hayas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looklex.com/e.o/ahl-e_haqq.htm|title=Ahl-e Haqq - LookLex Encyclopaedia|first=Tore|last=Kjeilen|website=looklex.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahle-haqq.com/rituals.html|title=Ahl-e Haqq - Rituals and Traditions|website=www.ahle-haqq.com}}</ref>
Every Yarsani therefore belongs to one specific khandan, which is led by a spiritual leader called a say-yed, to whom each member must swear obedience. The say-yed is the spiritual leader of the community and is normally present during the ceremonies attended by the followers. Say-yeds are the only ones allowed to have full access to the religious texts of Yarsanism, and have traditionally competed with each other to have the largest number of followers. The position of Say-yed is hereditary, being passed down through the generations from the original founders. As the say-yed are considered spiritual 'parents', it is the tradition for them not to marry their followers.
==Demographics== The majority of Yarsanis are found in the Kurdish areas of Iran and Iraq, especially in [[Hawraman]] and the [[Kermanshah province]] of Iran.
===In Iran=== {{main|Goran Kurds|Kurdish people}} The Yarsani in Iran are mostly found in [[Lorestan Province|Lorestan]] and [[Kermanshah province]]s<ref name="auto"/> There are also large communities of Yarsanis in some regions of [[Iranian Azerbaijan]]. The town of [[Ilkhichi]] (İlxıçı), which is located 87 km south west of [[Tabriz]] is almost entirely populated by Yarsanis. {{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} For political reasons, one of which was to create a distinct identity for these communities, they have not been called [[Goran Kurds]] since the early 20th century.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} They are called various names, such as [[Ali-Ilahis]] and Ahl-e Haqq. Both the [[Dersim]] ''([[Zazaki]] / [[Zaza people|Zaza]])'' people and the [[Southern Kurdish|Gorani]], who speak a language that is considered to belong to the [[Hawrami|Hawramani]] branch of the North West [[Iranian languages]], adhere to a form of Kurdish [[Alawites|Alawi faith]] which resembles the religions of the [[Yezidi]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Kurdish Culture and Society, an Annotated Bibliography|page=8|first1=Lokman I. |first2=Kelly L. |last1=Meho |last2=Maglaughlin |year=2001 |isbn=0-313-31543-4|url=https://books.google.pt/books?id=sl4PIeyWriUC&pg=PA8}}</ref> [[Ali-Illahism|Ali-Ilahians]] or [[Druze]].
===In Iraq=== The Yarsani are known in Iraq as the '''Kaka'i'''. There are Yarsani in Iraqi Kurdistan, around [[Kirkuk]] and [[Sulaymaniyah]].<ref name="auto"/> The speakers of [[Sarli dialect|Sarli,]] living near [[Al-Hamdaniya District|Eski Kalak]] in Iraq, are adherents, as [[Cecil J. Edmonds|Edmonds]] (1957: 195) surmised and Moosa (1988: 168) observed. ===In Turkey=== Yarsanis are also found in some rural communities in southeastern [[Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looklex.com/e.o/ahl-e_haqq.htm|title=Ahl-e Haqq - LookLex Encyclopaedia|author=Tore Kjeilen|publisher=|accessdate=23 August 2015}}</ref>
==Relationship with other religious groups== [[File:Dukkan-e Davood (4130696198).jpg|150px|thumb|right|Rock carving at Dukkan-e Davood]] A group of native, allegedly Iranian, but archaeologically [[Mesopotamian]], monotheistic religions practiced by Kurds consisting of [[Yarsani]] and [[Êzidî]] along with [[Chinarism|Chinarism/Ishikism ''(Ishik Alevism)'']] are claimed as "[[Yazdânism]]" by [[Mehrdad Izady]].<ref name="Izady">{{Citation |last=Izady |first=Mehrdad R. |year=1992 |title=The Kurds: A Concise Handbook |publication-place=Washington & London |publisher=Taylor & Francis |pages=170 passim |isbn=0-8448-1727-9}}</ref>
An excerpt from the French Review of the Muslim World<ref>{{cite journal |title=Notes sur la sect des Ahlé-Haqq |journal=Revue du Monde Musulman |year=1920 |last=Minorsky |first=Vladimir |authorlink=Vladimir Minorsky |volume=40-41 |page=20 |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k103836s/f24.image |accessdate=2017-03-25|language=french}}</ref> describes the difficulty in nomenclature for Yarsanism and related Shi'ite mysticism. The English translation reads:
{{quote|First of all, we must clear up the confusion resulting from the variety of names given to the sect of "Ahlé-Haqq", which are liable to be misunderstood. Like any religion, the one we are dealing with considers itself to be the only true and orthodox one, and it is natural that its adherents give themselves the name of "People of Truth" (''Ahlé-Haqq'' or ''Ahlé-Haqîqat''). This term lacks precision, as other sects, for example the [[Hurufism|Horoufis]], occasionally apply it to themselves. Still, the name Ahlé-Haqq to refer to the sect of our particular interest has every advantage over appellations such as "[[Ghulat|Gholat]]", "[[Ali-Illahism|Alî-Allâhi]]", and "[[Alawites|Noséïri]]" that the Muslims and most European travellers use in speaking of them. The first term, which encompasses all of the extremist Shi’ites, is too broad and too vague. The second term, "deifiers of Ali", has the same fault and emphasizes what is only a detail in the religious system under discussion. Finally, the name "[[Nusairi|Noséïri]]" belongs to that well-defined Syrian religion, which, despite some resemblances with the doctrines of the Ahlé-Haqq (the worship of Ali, the communion, etc.), appears to present a complex of quite different old beliefs.}}
===Relations with Islam=== ''Ahl-e Haqq'' view Islam as a product of a cycle of divine essence, which was made manifest in [[Ali]], and established the stage of [[Sharia|''shai'at'']] (Islamic law). This was followed by the cycle of [[Tariqa|''tariqat'']] (Sufi teachings), then ''[[ma'rifa]]t'' (Sufi gnosis), and finally the current cycle of [[haqiqa]]t (Ultimate Truth), which was made manifest in [[Sultan Sahak]]. The final stage supersedes the previous ones, which frees Ahl-e Haqq from observing the shari'a rules incumbent on Muslims. Ahl-i Haqq class other Muslims as either Ahl-i Tashayyu (followers of Shi'ism) or Ahl-i Tasannun (followers of Sunnism). The Ahl-i Haqq neither observe Muslim rites, such as daily prayers and fasting during the month of Ramadan, nor share Islamic theology and sacred space, such as belief in the day of resurrection and sanctity of the mosque.<ref>Z. Mir-Hosseini, "Inner Truth and Outer History: The Two Worlds of the Ahl-e Haqq of Kurdistan", ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'', Vol.26, 1994, p.267–268</ref>
Extremist Sunni Islamic groups such as the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] and [[al-Qaeda]] regard the followers of Yarsanism as unbelievers who have to convert to Islam or die. These militants have prosecuted Yarsanis during the [[Iraq conflict (2003–present)|Iraq conflict]], possibly prompting some Iraqi Yarsan community leaders to declare in 2013 that their people were actually Muslims to avoid sectarian attacks.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/islamic-state-terror-group-surges-iraq-disputed-territories/4455890.html |title=IS Terror Group Surges in Iraq's Disputed Territories |author=Rikar Hussein |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=4 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/iraq-islamic-state-kakai-minority/4455712.html |title=IS Attacks Drive Members of Iraqi Kakai Minority From Their Villages |author=Dilshad Anwar |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=1 July 2018 }}</ref>

Yazda was established to support the [[Yazidi]], who are a minority [[ethnoreligious group]] around the world, especially in northern [[Iraq]], specifically [[Sinjar]] and [[Nineveh Plain]], and northeastern [[Syria]], where the Yazidi community has, as part of a deliberate "military, economic, and political strategy," been the focus of a [[genocide|genocidal]] campaign by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]]{{cite news|last1=Kikoler|first1=Naomi|title=Iraq Bearing Witness Trip Report: "Our Generation is Gone" The Islamic State's Targeting of Iraqi Minorities in Ninewa|url=https://www.ushmm.org/m/pdfs/Iraq-Bearing-Witness-Report-111215.pdf|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=Simon-Skjodt Center for the Prevention of Genocide|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|date=12 November 2015}}{{rp|3}} that included mass murder, the separation of families, forced religious conversions, forced marriages, sexual assault, physical assault, torture, kidnapping, and slavery.{{cite news|title=Iraq: Protect Mass Graves. Evidence of Possible ISIS Genocide Endangered|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/01/30/iraq-protect-mass-graves|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=30 January 2016|location=[[Dohuk]]}}{{cite news|last1=Callimachi|first1=Rukmini|title=ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/14/world/middleeast/isis-enshrines-a-theology-of-rape.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 August 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Begikhani|first1=Nazand|title=Opinion: Why ISIS's treatment of Yazidi women is genocide - CNN.com|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/30/opinion/isis-yazidi-women-genocide/|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[CNN]]|date=30 October 2014}} == History == In August 2014, Yazda was founded by a group of [[Yazidi]] and Yazidi American activists in the United States centered around Yazidi communities in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]], [[Nebraska]],{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Dave|last2=McCartney|first2=Rob|last3=Petersen|first3=Brandi|title=Nebraskan Yazidis want to stop carnage by Islamic State in Iraq|url=http://www.ketv.com/news/nebraskan-yazidis-want-to-stop-carnage-by-islamic-state-in-iraq/29633206|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[KETV]]|date=10 November 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Jack|title=Yazidis from Iraq Find Welcome Refuge in Nebraska|url=http://netnebraska.org/article/news/1108600/yazidis-iraq-find-welcome-refuge-nebraska|work=[[Nebraska Educational Telecommunications|NET Nebraska]]|date=14 December 2017|format=Includes audio}} and [[Houston]], [[Texas]].{{cite news|last1=Flakus|first1=Greg|title=America’s Heartland Helps Iraq's Yazidis|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/america-heartland-helps-yazidis-in-iraq/2919092.html|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Voice of America]]|date=14 August 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Flakus|first1=Greg|title=Yazidi-American Activist Seeks Help for Refugees|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/yazidi-american-activist-seeks-help-refugees/2986102.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Voice of America]]|date=30 September 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Flakus|first1=Greg|title=Yazidi Americans Seek Help for their People|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/yazidi-americans-sek-help-for-their-people/2988456.html|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Voice of America]]|date=1 October 2015}} In addition to education initiatives that explain Yazidi culture and religion, Yazda runs a Yazda's Center in [[Kurdistan]], [[Iraq]], and assists victims of the genocide and rape that began in Iraq in 2014.{{cite news|last1=Wheeler|first1=Skye|title=Yezidi Women After Slavery: Trauma|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/04/18/yezidi-women-after-slavery-trauma|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=18 April 2016}} The first mission of Yazda was advocating in the United States during ISIL's attack on [[Sinjar]]. Yazda helped by providing humanitarian assistance in the form of food and water to approximately 60,000 [[Yazidis]], who were stranded on mountain Sinjar by ISIL during the week of August 3, 2014. At this point, Yazda began its work trying to locate and help free Yazidi women and girls, more than 3,200 of whom were captured, enslaved, and are still held hostage by the Islamic State.{{cite news|title=3,000 Girls and Women Sold as Sex Slaves By ISIS, Chicago Student Heads to Iraq to Save Them|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2015/09/15/yazidi-girls-women-sex-slaves/|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[WBBM-TV]] – CBS Chicago|date=15 September 2016}} Those women and girls are victims of human trafficking and sexual slavery. Yazda's center in Iraq functions as a local [[non-governmental organization|non-governmental organization (NGO)]].{{cite web|title=Yazda: Road to Peace Registered Charity number 1165299|url=http://www.roadtopeace.org.uk/yazda|website=Road to Peace|accessdate=23 September 2016}} Yazda sponsored multiple online petitions to focus on helping captured and enslaved Yazidi women.{{cite news|last1=Rubin|first1=Trudy|title=Trudy Rubin: Who will save Yazidi victims of Islamic State rape?|url=http://www.amestrib.com/opinion/trudy-rubin-who-will-save-yazidi-victims-islamic-state-rape|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Ames Tribune]]|date=7 September 2015}} Activists working with Yazda asked [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] to help the women and girls still held captive.{{cite news|last1=Pirali|first1=Feryal|last2=Yazda|title=Barack Obama: Help the Yazidi women and girls enslaved by ISIS|url=http://www.yazda.org/change-org-petition/|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Change.org]]|date=2015}} A Yazidi high school student from International Development]] [[Justine Greening]], and [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs]] [[Philip Hammond]], for a meeting to discuss providing solutions to the crisis.{{cite news|last1=Bannister|first1=Antonia|title=Teen who fled Iraq calls on Government to help girls who escape Telegraph]]|date=23 July 2015}} In August 2015, [[Luis Moreno Ocampo]], former Prosecutor of the [[International Criminal Court]], activist Kerry Propper, and multi-media communication specialist Elizabeth Schaeffer Brown, came to the Yazda Center in [[Dohuk]], [[Kurdistan]], to gather testimony and record victim statements. They proceeded to launch [[It's On U]], a lobbying campaign to pressure heads of state and UN Security Council members to refer the Yazdi genocide to the ICC.{{cite news|last1=Schaeffer Brown|first1=Elizabeth|title=Women aim to bring ISIS to justice with their stories of captivity, torture and daring escape|url=http://nytlive.nytimes.com/womenintheworld/2016/04/27/women-aim-to-bring-isis-to-justice-with-their-stories-of-captivity-torture-and-daring-escape/|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 April 2016}} === International Criminal Court === On September 25, 2015, Yazda and Free Yazidi Foundation, with the support of the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|Kurdish Regional Government of Iraq]], submitted a detailed report to the [[International Criminal Court|International Criminal Court (ICC)]] that explains how ISIL, with a disproportionate number of foreign fighters, committed genocide against the Yazidi people.{{cite news|last1=Sterling|first1=Toby|title=Persecuted by Islamic State, Yazidis turn to ICC for justice|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-icc-yazidis-idUSKCN0RO14G20150924|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Reuters]]|date=24 September 2015|location=The Hague}}{{cite State|url=https://news.vice.com/article/yazidi-groups-plead-with-international-criminal-court-to-prosecute-genocide-by-islamic-state|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice News]]|date=24 September 2015}} The report requested a formal investigation into the crimes of the Islamic State (ISIS) to be conducted by the international community to prosecute ISIL for the crime Court|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/world/middleeast/iraq-yazidis-turn-to-international-court.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 September 2015}} Because Iraq is not a signatory of the [[Rome Statute]] of the [[International Criminal Court|International Criminal Court (ICC)]], there is a limitation to the assistance the ICC can provide. One option would be that the ICC could be granted limited jurisdiction over the region.{{cite news|last1=Coles|first1=Isabel|title=Former ICC chief prosecutor pushes for Yazidi genocide case|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/09/02/Former-ICC-chief-prosecutor-pushes-for-Yazidi-genocide-case.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=2 September 2015}} === Nadia Murad === Yazda provides assistance and support to the Yazidi activist, [[Nadia Murad]], a [[Yazidi]] [[Human rights activists|human rights activist]],{{cite web|last1=Khudida|first1=Ahmed|url=http://www.yazda.org/a-statement-by-nadia-murad-and-yazdas-communication-team-on-nadia-and-yazda-visit-to-australia/|title=A Statement by prize|url=http://ekurd.net/yazidi-nadia-murad-nobel-prize-2016-01-06|accessdate=22 September 2016|work=Ekurd Daily|date=6 January 2016|location=Baghdad}}{{cite survivor on a mission to save Yazidi women and girls|url=http://www.newsweek.com/nadia-murad-isis-sex-slavery-yazidi-438421|accessdate=22 September 2016|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=19 March 2016}} On September 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Elise|title=Amal Clooney, George’s wife, takes on U.N. and ISIS|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/sep/19/amal-clooney-takes-on-isis-at-un/|accessdate=22 September 2016|work=[[The Washington Times]]|date=19 September 2016}} === Organization === Yazda is run by teams of volunteers in the [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Sweden]], [[Germany]], and [[Iraq]]. A large portion of the volunteers emigrated after working as translators during the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] and in other conflicts that involved the U.S. military. Chicago graduate student, Matthew Barber, was Executive Director for a period of one year. Murad Ismael, co-founder of Yazda, is the current Executive Director. == Projects == Yazda supports survivors of the Yazidi genocide through numerous aid and relief programs. Yazda has a Medical Center in Iraq and supports thousands of people in need of primary medical care and first aid services. Yazda also has a mobile clinic in Sinjar to support the Yazidis in the remote areas and villages around Sinjar. Yazda conducts missions to provide humanitarian aids and relief services of clean water, clothing, and food to as many displaced people as possible.{{cite news|last1=Shevardnadze|first1=Sophie|title=Children born to ISIL sex slaves are taken to be trained into murderers – Yazidi aid worker|url=https://www.rt.com/shows/sophieco/324712-children-isil-sex-slaves/|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT International]]|date=4 December 2015|language=en-EN|format=Video}} === Genocide documentation === The genocide documentation project started on the October 17, 2014. Yazda worked with the Voices of Rwanda, an organization that has been documenting the Rwanda's genocide, to train and support Yazda's documentation team. The team works on recording Yazidi survivors and eyewitness testimonies of the genocidal campaign. The team locates and investigates the mass graves of Yazidis.{{cite news|last1=Beck|first1=John|title=Iraq's Yazidis living in fear on Mount Sinjar|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/iraq-yazidis-living-fear-mount-sinjar-160726063155982.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=26 July 2016}}{{cite news|title=ISIS buried thousands in 72 mass graves|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/2016/08/30/ISIS-buried-thousands-in-72-mass-graves.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|date=30 August 2016|location=Hardan, Iraq}} In 2016, Yazda and [[Human Rights Watch]] issued an official report regarding the discovered mass graves.{{cite book|last1=Barber|first1=Matthew|last2=Khalaf|first2=Ali|last3=Slater|first3=Andrew|last4=Chomer|first4=Jameel Ghanem|last5=‘Ajo|first5=Mahmood|title=A Report from the Yazda Documentation Project on Mass Graves of Yazidis Killed by the Islamic State Organization or Local Affiliates On or After August 3, 2014|date=28 January 2016|publisher=Yazda|url=https://docs.google.com/viewerng/viewer?url=http://www.yazda.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Yazda-Report-on-Mass-Graves-Jan-28-2016.pdf}} Regarding this matter, Yazda had urged the international community to formally investigate the mass graves before evidence was lost at those sites because of the fact that Sinjar is still a war zone and the sites of genocide are unprotected. The team also investigates the general devastation of Yazidi community and damage of Yazidis properties following ISIL's attack, and has worked in support of assisting Western media to document the story.{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Erika|title=Kidnapping and Sex Slavery: Covering ISIS’ Religious Justification for Rape|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/14/insider/kidnapping-and-sex-slavery-covering-isiss-religious-justification-for-rape.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 August 2015}} === Psycho-social support and Women's Center === Yazda began a psycho-social program in its center in [[Dohuk]], [[Iraq]], for the Yazidi women and girls who managed to escape or are rescued from ISIL. The women and girls suffer from severe physical and mental abuse and require post-trauma support.{{cite news|last1=KRG Cabinet|title=KRG officials call upon the international community to help abducted Kurdish Yezidi women|url=http://cabinet.gov.krd/a/d.aspx?s=040000&l=12&a=52363|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=حکومەتی هەرێمی كوردستان [[Kurdistan Regional Government]]|date=16 October 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Soguel|first1=Dominique|title=For Yazidis traumatized by Islamic State horrors, few mental health resources|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2015/1007/For-Yazidis-traumatized-by-Islamic-State-horrors-few-mental-health-resources|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=7 October 2015}} Yazda helps them recover from the trauma and reintegrate into society via response programs to help the women with methods that include individual therapy and often require long-term treatment.{{cite news|last1=Sesay|first1=Isha|title=Looking at the plight of the Yazidis|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AD7rq89VTeQ|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[CNN]]|date=17 September 2015|format=Video}} ISIL's genocidal campaign against the Yazidis resulted in the abduction and enslavement of thousands Yazidis, the majority of which were women and girls. Yazda volunteers and the office of Yazidi affairs in Kurdistan have collected the names of approximately 5,000 abducted Yazidis after the genocidal campaign. These abductees were subjected to systematic sexual abuse and rape, and those who still held hostage face the same daily abuses even to the present day.{{cite news|last1=Gilbert|first1=Benjamin|title=ISIS is still holding nearly 2,000 Yazidi women as slaves|url=https://news.vice.com/article/isis-is-still-holding-nearly-2000-yazidi-women-as-slaves|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|VICE News]]|date=20 August 2016}}{{cite news|title=ISIS tightens grip on women held as sex slaves|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2016/07/06/ISIS-tightens-grip-on-women-held-as-sex-slaves.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|date=6 July 2016|location=Khanke, Iraq}} By the beginning of 2016, over 2,000 abducted Yazidi women and girls returned to freedom, either by escaping or by being rescued. Many cases of rescue or escape involve women and girls being reunited with destitute families in the rough conditions of [[internally displaced person|Internally Displaced Person (IDP)]] [[displaced persons camp|camps]] or squalid conditions of other locations where displaced families have taken refuge. Some escapees have lost all relatives to ISIL's massacres and did not have immediate families to return to. Through its case management program, Yazda has collected the information of more than 800 women and girls that have escaped ISIL individually.{{cite news|title=NGO helps Iraqi Kurdish Yazidi women overcome abuse at hands of Islamic State|url=http://ekurd.net/ngo-helps-yazidi-women-2015-11-06|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=Ekurd Daily|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=6 November 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Ismael|first1=Murad|title=2015 Trust Women Action: 'Support for Yazidi Women and Girls victimized by ISIS'|url=http://www.trustwomenconf.com/actions/i/?id=62a5c9be-de9e-46bf-9a18-6df479d77819|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Trust Women Conference]]|date=2015}} In addition to psycho-social therapy, Yazda provides survivors with shelter, food, clothing, fuel, and other basic necessities.{{cite news|last1=Callimachi|first1=Rukmini|last2=Stack|first2=Liam|last3=Barber|first3=Matthew|title=Middle East Q. And A.: The Culture of Rape Within ISIS, and the Questions That Arise|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/20/world/middleeast/the-culture-of-rape-within-isis-and-the-questions-that-arise.html|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 March 2016}} Yazda aims is to create an environment that is conducive to the healing of trauma survivors. Yazda provides medical and psychological treatment to help them recover from the damage they have experienced. Yazda struggles to provide adequate psycho-social resources and medical services to the survivors.{{cite news|last1=Leber|first1=Jessica|title=How Humanitarians Are Crowdsourcing Evidence Of A Genocide By ISIS|url=https://www.fastcoexist.com/3063443/how-humanitarians-are-crowdsourcing-evidence-of-a-genocide-by-isis|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=FastCoExist|date=20 September 2016}} === Yazda medical mission === ==== The Essyan Camp Primary Health Care Center ==== Yazda opened a medical clinic in the Esseyan [[displaced persons camp|camp]] to provide the displaced Yazidis with basic medical care.{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Olivia|title=Forgotten Yazidis face dire winter ahead|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/10/25/forgotten-yazidis-face-dire-winter-ahead.html|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=25 October 2015}} Yazda has managed to support the people in need with primary care services with the support of the Health Directorate of [[Dohuk]]. Through an agreement with the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|Kurdistan Regional Government's]] Department of Health, Yazda has the responsibility of providing all medical services to the population of the Essyan IDP camp. The population of the camp exceeds 14,600 people. Yazda maintains a physical health center, and has a staff of 17-member team of nurses, pharmacists, physician’s assistants, and lab assistants, in addition to several doctors. Yazda’s sources of funding are the donations from private donors and organizations. ==== Mount Sinjar Mobile Medical Clinic ==== Yazda had established a mobile clinic to serve the displaced Yazidis who still live on the [[Sinjar]] mountain area. According to Yazda, Yazda's mobile clinic plays a significant role in covering the needs of the people in remote areas of Sinjar and surrounding villages with a population of around 30,000 people.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Jonathan|title=For Yazidi girls escaping ISIL, a long road to healing|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/07/yazidi-girls-isil-raped-150722093100221.html|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=22 July 2015}} The German charitable organization, Zentralrat der Yeziden in Deutschland, provided an ambulance for the mission and sent medication and medical supplies.{{cite news|last1=Kuchta|first1=Thorsten|title=Is-Terror: Zeichen der Hoffnung aus Oldenburg|url=http://www.nwzonline.de/oldenburg/politik/zeichen-der-hoffnung-aus-oldenburg_a_30,0,3199329908.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=Nordwest-Zeitung|date=18 August 2015}} ==== Public Health Education Campaign ==== Yazda works to educate and provide outreach on proper food sanitation procedures to reduce instances of [[foodborne illness]], provides [[first aid]] education from within populations at [[internally displaced person|internally displaced person (IDP)]] [[displaced persons camp|camp]] and provide basic instructions on emergency response for instances where trained medical professional assistance is not available. === Aid work === Yazda provides food, water, clothes, and other necessities for the orphans of escaped women, and other people in need in IDP camps.{{cite news|title=Support Group Helps Yazidi Women Overcome Abuse at Hands of IS|url=http://www.nrttv.com/EN/Details.aspx?Jimare=4029|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[NRT News]]|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=6 November 2015}} The focus is on assisting the displaced Yazidi, which is estimated to be more than 90% of Iraq's original Yazidi population.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Jonathan|title=Yazidis leave Europe and return to warring Iraq|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/04/yazidis-leave-europe-return-warring-iraq-160404074817769.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=9 May 2016}} === Tîrêja Rojê (Ray of the Sun): Preservation of Yazidi culture and religion === Tîrêja Rojê is Yazda’s project for the preservation of the Yazidi religious and cultural tradition. The project involves sharing historical traditions and cultural knowledge by older generations to younger generations. It also provides psychological therapy to help the displaced Yazidis recover from genocide trauma. === Qalam Zerin (Golden Pen) === Qalam Zerin is a project run the Yazidi poet, Murad Allo, that provides Yazidi university students mentorship and support in the form of weekly meetings on topics that include languages classes, public speaking, writing, and maintaining physical health. The project focuses on rehabilitating Yazidi youth through activities that include oral lectures, paintings, poetry, writing classes, and various cultural activities to treat collective trauma for the Yazidi society through the youth. === Education and support for children === Yazda provides assistance to children visiting the Yazda Women's Center in Duhok, with planned outreach for displaced children who need sponsorship and adoption services, direct aid, and trauma, medical, and education support. == See also == * [[Nadia Murad]] * [[Yazidis]] * [[Ezidkhan]] * [[Êzîdxan Protection Force]] * [[Genocide of Yazidis by ISIL]] * [[Sinjar massacre]] * [[Chibok girls]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|last1=Yazda|last2=The Free Yezidi Foundation|last3=Kurdistan Regional Government of Iraq|title=ISIL: Nationals of ICC states parties committing genocide and other crimes against the Yazidis|date=September 2015|publisher=Yazda / The Free Yezidi Foundation|url=http://www.yazda.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/RED-ISIL-commiting-genocide-against-the-Yazidis.pdf}} * {{cite book|last1=Yazda|title=Yazda Report on Humanitarian Aid and Development Opportunities in Sinjar: Caring for IDPs While Rebuilding and Facilitating Returns|date=20 December 2015|edition=version 1.3 -
